introduction.p: You have probably seen colored bands on soap bubbles. from Wikipedia show separation of colors by a soap film. This is different than the separation of colors when rainbow forms across the sky. Rainbow occurs occurs due to difference in refractive index for different colors. Here, as we will see below, the pattern is due to interference of two reflected waves. A soap film is a thin film of water and we get light reflected from front at air/water interface and another reflection from water/air interface at the back of the film facing inside of the bubble. Since the angles of interference depend on the wavelength, you see different colors in different directions. You also see repeat of color pattern due to the different orders of interference as we saw in Young's double slit experiment in .

figure.caption: Interference fringes from a soap film. Credits: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soap_bubble#/media/File:Macro_Photography_of_a_soap_bubble.jpg

introduction.p: Actually, you can get interference patttern from any transparent thin film such as a thin sheet of glass, or plastic, or airgap, etc. We will use to study interference from dielectric films where a light from a monochromatic source is incident on a film and reflected waves from the front and back are brought to a common point at a screen. We will examine one representative ray at incident angle \theta.

figure.caption: Interference from reflections from two sides of a planar film.

introduction.p: Let d be the thickness of the film and n_1,\ n_2,\ n_3 be the refractive indices of the media of the incident ray, the film and the media behind the film. Note that in the soap film, n_1 and n_3 are both for air and n_2 is that of water.

The amplitide of the incident wave PA is split at the n_1/n_2 interface into a reflected part in AD and a transmitted part in AB. The transmitted part, then travels to the n_2/n_3 interface, where its amplitude splits into a reflected part in BC and a transmitted part which we will ignore in the present discussion.

The reflected ray BC travels back to the n_1/n_2 interface and refracts into the first medium in the direction \text{CC}^{\prime}, which travels parallel to the ray AD. We bring the parallel rays to a point of the focal plane, which is labeled Q, of a converging lens. The parallel rays represent two waves. Therefore, their superposition will display interference and you will see constructive or destructive interference depending upon the difference in their phases at that point.

You might have already noticed that there are infintely many reflected rays that will be coming back into n_1 medium by rays reflecting back and forth inside the plate. Here we will look at just first two waves since amplitudes of other waves will be considerably less than these two. Another thing you should notice is that we could very well bring multiple transmitted waves together on the other side of the plate for interference. We will not do this calculation here, but you might want to do that, just for practice.

I will present calculations for interference conditions in subsections below. Here let us summarize the results for a quick look up for the most common case n_1=n_3\lt n_2. The formula for interference conditons take simpler form when written using the refraction angle \theta_r rather than the incidence angle \theta and the wavelength \lambda_2 of light in the film.
\amp \text{Constructive: } 2 d \cos\theta_r = m\frac{\lambda_2}{2} \ \ (m\ \text{ odd}) \amp \text{Destructive: } 2 d \cos\theta_r = m^\prime \lambda_2 \ \ (m^\prime\ \text{ integer})
where m odd, m^\prime, \lambda_2, and \theta_r are
\amp m = \pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 5, \cdots, \amp m^\prime = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \pm 3, \cdots, \amp \lambda_2 = \frac{\lambda_0}{n_2}, \amp n_2 \sin\theta_r = n_1 \sin\theta,\ \ \text{Snell's law.}
Note that not all m and m^\prime will be possible since we must obey
-1.0 \le \cos\theta_r \le +1.
We can write the conditions in terms of incidence (and obviously same reflected angle) \theta, telling the direction in whih we need to look for the interference.
\amp \text{Constructive: } \sin\theta = \frac{1}{4n_1 d} \sqrt{ 16 n_2^2d^2- m^2\lambda_0^2 } \ \ (m\ \text{ odd}) \amp \text{Destructive: } \sin\theta = \frac{1}{2n_1 d} \sqrt{ 4 n_2^2d^2- {m^\prime}^2\lambda_0^2 } \ \ (m^\prime\ \text{ integer})
In these formulas, you need to restrict m and m^\prime so that your results are real numbers and values of \sin\theta makes sense.
\amp -1.0\le \sin\theta\le 1.0,\ \ |m^\prime| \le \frac{2 n_2 d}{\lambda_0},\ \ |m| \le \frac{4 n_2 d}{\lambda_0}.

For a nearly normal reflection, angles of incidence and refraction will be zero. This is the situation when you are looking at a film nearly vertically to the film. This would give an interference condition that would depend on the thickness of the film and the wave length. Setting \cos\theta_r=1 in Eqs. and , we will see constructive and desctrctive interferences if thickness of the film corresponds to the following conditions.
\amp \text{Constructive: } 2 d = m\frac{\lambda_2}{2} \ \ (m\ \text{ odd}) \amp \text{Destructive: } 2 d = m^\prime \lambda_2 \ \ (m^\prime\ \text{ integer})
This result is useful in understanding why we see different colors in a soap film evern when we look at it nearly normally - the explanation has to do with varying thickness of the film. At different points thickness is just right for say purple light to be constructive and at some nearby location it is just right for green light to be constructive, etc.

exercise.title: Thickness of a Soap Film from Wavelength of the Reflected Light

statement.p: A soap film reflects blue light of wavelength, which has the value of 0.475\,\mu\text{m} in vacuum, when viewed normally. Find the thickness of the film at the site where the reflection is occuring from if the soap water has a refractive index of 1.33? Assume the interference observed is of order 1.

hint.p: Use the formula for the normal incidence.

solution.p:
To use the interference formula, first we need to evaluate the wavelength \lambda_2 inside the soap film, which is different from 0.475\,\mu\text{m}.
\lambda_2 = \frac{\lambda_0}{n_2} = \frac{0.475\,\mu\text{m}}{1.33} = 0.375\,\mu\text{m}.
We find the thickness of the soap film by using order number to be m = 1 in the constructive interference condition. Of course, using other values of order would give other thicknesses.
d = \frac{1}{2}\ \frac{\lambda_2}{2} = \frac{1}{2}\ \frac{0.375\,\mu\text{m}}{2} = 0.893 \,\mu\text{m}.

subsection.title: Derivation of Interference Conditions for Dielectric Film
subsection.p:
In this section we will work out the formulas I have given above for the most common case of use, viz., n_1=n_3\lt n_2, such as air/glass/air. Since we only wish to find the interference conditions and not actual values of intensities, we do not need to do a full calcualtion using the electric field wave. We can actually derive the conditions using a few simple rules.
1. When a wave in a medium n_{first} is incident on a medium n_{second}, then reflected wave will have additional phase change by \pi radians if n_{first} \lt n_{second}, otherwise no additional phase change occurs.
1. Wave length in a medium depends on refractive index. Thus, if wavelength in vacuum is \lambda_0, then refractive index in a medium of refractive index n will be
\lambda = \frac{\lambda_0}{n}.
3. For each wavelength traveled, phase changes by 2\pi radians.

Now, let us redraw the figure for reflections from a thin film (see ) so that we can use it here rather than switch back and forth from above. We wish to calculate the phase difference between the wave going in paths PADD'Q and PABCC'Q. Note that phase changes on DD'Q and CC'Q are same, so they cancel out in the difference and we need to only consider paths PAD and PABC.

figure.caption: Interference from reflections from two sides of a planar film.

subsection.p:
Now, we can find the phase change for traveling a distance AD in the first medium by noting that phase of a wave changes by 2\pi radians when it travels one wavelength in the medium. We must be careful here and use the correct wavelength for each path since waves are traveling in different media. We are using \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 for the wavelength in the two media. Note that although the frequency of light is same in the two media, the wavelength will be different in the two media because speed of the wave depends on the refractive index.
\amp \lambda_1 = \frac{v_1}{f} = \frac{c}{n_1 f}
\amp \lambda_2 = \frac{v_2}{f} = \frac{c}{n_2 f}
Therefore, we will have the following relation between the wavelengths.
n_2 \lambda_2 = n_1 \lambda_1.
Hence, phase changes over the two paths are as follows.
\amp \text{phase change over AD}= \frac{\text{AD}}{\lambda_1}\times 2\pi.
\amp \text{phase change over AB}= \frac{\text{AB}}{\lambda_2}\times 2\pi = \frac{n_2}{n_1} \frac{\text{AB}}{\lambda_1}\times 2\pi.
\amp \text{phase change over BC}= \frac{\text{BC}}{\lambda_2}\times 2\pi = \frac{n_2}{n_1} \frac{\text{BC}}{\lambda_1}\times 2\pi.
Therefore phase difference between the two waves will be
\Delta_{12} = \pi + \frac{2\pi}{\lambda_1}\left[ \text{AD} - \frac{n_2}{n_1} \left(\text{AB} + \text{BC} \right) \right].
We can replace the distances AB, BC, and AD in terms of the thickness d of the film, angle of incidence \theta and angle of refraction \theta_r.
\text{AB} \amp = \text{BC} = \frac{d}{\cos\theta_r} \text{AD} \amp = \text{AC} \sin\theta = 2 d \tan\theta_r \sin\theta \amp = 2d \frac{n_2}{n_1}\ \frac{\sin^2\theta_r}{\cos\theta_r},
where I have made use of the Snell's law for the refraction at A, n_1\sin\theta = n_2 \sin\theta_r. Substituting for AB, BC and AD in the expression for \Delta_{12} gives
\Delta_{12} = \pi + \frac{2\pi}{\lambda_2} \times 2d \cos\theta_r.
The interference will be constructive if this is integer multiple of 2\pi and destructive if odd multiple of \pi.
\amp \text{Constructive: } \Delta_{12} = n\times 2\pi \ \ (n\ \text{ integer}) \amp \text{Destructive: } \Delta_{12} = n^\prime \pi\ \ (n^\prime\ \text{ odd})
We can send \pi on the other side, simplify, and replace n and n^\prime by appropriate m and m^\prime. Due to moving \pi to the right side, the choice of m is different than that of n.
\amp \text{Constructive: } 2 d \cos\theta_r = m\frac{\lambda_2}{2} \ \ (m\ \text{ odd}) \amp \text{Destructive: } 2 d \cos\theta_r = m^\prime \lambda_2 \ \ (m^\prime\ \text{ integer})

subsection.title: Reflected Waves from a Wedge-shaped Film
subsection.p: A wedge is a simple system of linearly varying thickness. The phase difference between the rays reflected from the top and the bottom of a wedge-shaped dielectric film will depend upon where on the wedge this happens. A set-up that makes use of the reflections from a wedge-shaped film is shown in . An extended source is used to strike at different parts of the wedge, and observations are made on the reflections of nearly normally incident rays.

figure.caption: Interference from reflection from two sides of a wedge.

subsection.p: We again consider the case n_1=n_3. If n_1\lt n_2, then the reflection at A will cause a phase shift of \pi radians and no phase shift for the reflection at B. If n_1=n_3>n_2, then the reflection at A will not cause phase shift but the reflection at B will cause phase shift of \pi radians. Therefore, as far as the phase shift contributions in the two waves labeled E_{1r} and E_{2r} are concerned, the situation here is similar to the plane plate worked out in the last section.

subsubsection.title: Newton's Rings
subsubsection.p: shows a hemispherical surface on a flat surface. This arrangment provides an interesting way to create air gap of varying heights. Reflections from top of glass/air and then air/glass interfaces interfere and one sees fringes. These fringes are called Newton's rings. Let us analyze this setup and find a formula for normal viewing.

figure.caption: A curved plate pressed against a flat plate provides layer of air with varying depths.

subsubsection.p:
The thickness d at a horizontal distance r from the center is given by the following relation from the Pythagoras theorem.
(R-d)^2 + r^2 = R^2.
Solve for d keeping the root with d\lt R.
d = R - \sqrt{R^2 - r^2}. The condition for constructive interference in case of near normal incidence is as follows.
d = R - \sqrt{R^2 - r^2} = \frac{m}{2} \frac{\lambda_0}{2}.
where m is an odd number and \lambda_0 is the wavelength in air, the medium of the wedge. The bright fringes form at following radial values from the center.
r = \sqrt{ \frac{m}{2} R \lambda_0 },
where we have assumed \lambda_0 \ll R and dropped a term. Since bright and dark fringes form in circles, they look like rings as illustrated in . Isaac Newton reported these rings in his book Optiks: or, a Treatise on the Reflexions, Refractions, Inflexions and Colours of Light. We now call these rings Newton's rings. Newton pressed a double convex lens against the curved sides of the planar convex lens to create wedge that produced colored rings.

figure.caption: Newton's rings are observed when viewd from above.

exercise.title: Interference of Laser Light Reflected from a Wedge

statement.p: A laser light of wavelength in air of 0.630\,\mu\text{m} is incident in the apparatus shown above. The slides are made of glass of refractive index 1.60, and the wedge is water with refractive index 1.33. Find the distance along x you need to move to go from one bright fringe to the next if the wedge angle is 5^\circ.

solution.p:
Let us work out the constructive interference conditions for m = 0 and m = 1. Note that the angle \alpha of the wedge must be expressed in radians. Denoting x_0 for x value when m=0 and x_1 when m=1 we get
\amp x_0 = \frac{1}{\alpha}\ \frac{\lambda_{\text{water}}}{4} = \frac{180}{5\times\pi}\ \frac{1}{4} \frac{ 1.0\times 0.630\,\mu\text{m}}{1.33} = 1.36\ \mu\text{m}. \amp x_1 = \frac{1}{\alpha}\ \frac{3 \lambda_{\text{water}}}{4} = 3x_0.
Hence, \Delta x = x_1-x_0 = 2x_0 = 2.72\ \mu\text{m}.

exercise.title: Calculating Phase Difference Between Two Optical Paths

statement.p: Two waves start from a coherent source. They travel the same physical distance of \frac{1}{2} meter. But there is a 10\text{ cm} thick glass of refractive index 1.53 in the path of one of the waves. What is the phase difference between the two waves if the wavelength is 530\text{ nm} in the air. Use refractive index of air = 1.00?

hint.p: Wavelength in glass is different than in air.

solution.p:
To find the phase difference between the two paths it is sufficient to find the phase difference over the 10 cm path when one wave goes through the glass and the other travels in air. There will be phase difference because the wavelengths of two lights of same frequency will be different in different media due to different refractive indices. Let us calculate the wavelength of the given light in glass of refractive index 1.53.
\lambda = \dfrac{\lambda_0}{n} = \dfrac{530\:\text{nm}}{1.53} = 346\:\text{nm}.
Now, when the wave goes through glass it makes one cycle every 346\:\text{nm} of travel distance. In each cycle the phase changes by 2\pi rad. Therefore, this wave will have the phase change in 10 cm in glass given by
\phi_1 = \left[ \dfrac{10\:\text{cm}}{346\:\text{nm}}\times 2\pi \right]\:\text{mod}\:2\pi.
Similarly, the wave through air will have the phase change by
\phi_2 = \left[ \dfrac{10\:\text{cm}}{530\:\text{nm}}\times 2\pi \right]\:\text{mod}\:2\pi.
Hence the phase difference between the two paths will be
\phi_1 - \phi_2 \amp = \left[ 20\pi\left(\dfrac{1}{346} - \dfrac{1}{530} \right) \times 10^7\right]\: \text{mod}\:2\pi \amp = 0.0958\: \text{rad} = 5.56^{\circ}.

exercise.title: Change in Interference When Glass Plate is Inserted in one Path

statement.p: A 530\text{-nm} light is incident on a double-slit of separation 5.0\ \mu\text{m}. When one of the slits is covered with a 2.0\ \mu\text{m} thick glass film of refractive index 1.5, interference pattern on a scren located 1.0\text{ m} is observed to move. Find the distance m = 1 constructive interference moves on the screen.

hint.p: The phase rotation in a medium of thickness x with refractive index n> will be 2\pi d/ (\lambda/n). Also path differece in direction \theta is just d\sin\theta where d is the distance between slits.

solution.p:
Let y corrdinate be pointed upward on the screen with origin at the symmetry axis. Then, m=1 constructive interference will be located at
d\sin\theta_1 = 1 \times \lambda,
from which can be written as y_1, the y coordinate there as
y_1 = \frac{\lambda L}{d} = \frac{0.530 \ \mu\text{m} \times 1.0\text{ m}}{5.0 \mu\text{m}} = 10.6\text{ cm}.
When we place a glass plate in one of the paths, the path difference d\sin\theta will be modified. Let t denote the thickness of the glass plate. So, we have phase changes in (d-t)\sin\theta with wavelength \lambda and t\sin\theta with wavelength \lambda/n. For =1 we want the net phase change to equal 2\pi. This gives
\frac{(d-t)\sin\theta}{\lambda}\times 2\pi + \frac{t\sin\theta}{\lambda/n}\times 2\pi = 1\times 2\pi.
Therefore, the condition now is
\sin\theta = \frac{\lambda}{d+(n-1)t}.
Replacing \sin\theta\approx y^\prime_1/L, where y^\prime_1 is the new location where m=1 constructive inteference will occur.
y^\prime_1 \amp = \frac{\lambda}{d+(n-1)t}\, L \amp = \frac{\lambda L}{d}\ \frac{1}{1+(n-1)t/d} = \frac{y_1}{1+(n-1)t/d} \amp = \frac{10.6\text{ cm}}{1+(1.5-1)2.0/5} = 8.83\text{ cm}
Therefore, m=1 spot will move by
|y^\prime_1-y_1| = 1.77\text{ cm}.

exercise.title: Thicknesss of an Oil Film on Glass from Wavelength of Light Observed at Normal

statement.p: When you look at a oily surface on a glass plate at a near normal angle, you find that it looks green. Let the wavelength of the light you see in air be 520\text{ nm}. The refractive index of oil is 1.25 and that of glass is 1.5. What could be the minimum thickness of the oil film?

hint.p: Note that you have n_1 \lt n_2 \lt n_3 here. Therefore, both reflections at n_1/n_2 and n_2/n_3 interfaces are now phase flipping.

solution.p: Thinking of oil film as a parallel plate. We have air/film/glass system with n_1 \lt n_2 \lt n_3. Both reflections at n_1/n_2 and n_2/n_3 interfaces are now phase flipping. Therefore, the condition for constructive and destructive interferences now, will be opposite of what we had for n_1 = n_3 \lt n_2, where only n_1/n_2 interface was phase flipping.

Now, the constructive interference will be
2 d \cos\theta_r = m \lambda_2\ \ (m\ \text{ integer})
Here, d is the thickness of the film. Near normal incidence \cos]theta_r=1. We also want smallest d. Therefore, we take m=1. Therefore, we have
d \amp = \frac{\lambda_2}{2} = \frac{\lambda}{2 n_\text{oil}} d \amp = \frac{520\text{ nm}}{2\times 1.25} = 208\text{ nm}.

exercise.title: Color of Very Thin Soap Film When Observed from Normal Direction

statement.p: What color will a 150 nm thick soap bubble appear if illuminated by a white light at near normal? Assume a refractive index of 1.4.

hint.p: Wavelengths of constructiely interfering ling may not be in the visible range.

solution.p:
Here we have
d = 150\:\text{nm},\ \ \lambda = \dfrac{\lambda_0}{n} = \dfrac{\lambda_0}{1.4}.
The constructive interference for the normal incidence
\amp m = 0 :\ \ d = \lambda/4,\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ \lambda_0 = 4\times 1.4\times 150\:\text{nm} = 840\:\text{nm}, \amp m = 1 :\ \ d = \left(1 + \dfrac{1}{2} \right)\dfrac{\lambda_0}{2\times 1.4},\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ \lambda_0 = 280\:\text{nm}.
The reflected light does not fall in the visible range. Therefore, the soap will appear black.

exercise.title: First Two Angles From Normal Direction of Bright Fringes from a Plastic Film

statement.p: A transparent plastic film has a thickness of 30\ \mu\text{m} and a refractive index of 1.45. Find the first two angles at which a green light of wavelength 530\text{ nm} will form bright fringes. Assume air on both sides of the film.

hint.p: Use the constructive interference formula for a dielectric film. Also note that order m is largest near normal.

solution.p:
Since we have n_1=n_3\lt n_2 case , we have the following condition for constructive interference with m an odd integer.
2d\:\cos\:\theta_r = m \lambda_2 = m \frac{\lambda}{n}.
Note that for near normal angles, we want \theta_r to be near zero. This will give us order m that we will look at.
m_\text{normal} = \left\lfloor \frac{2nd}{\lambda}\right\rfloor.
This will give
m_\text{normal} = \left\lfloor \frac{2\times 1.45\times 30\ \mu\text{m}}{0.530\ \mu\text{m}}\right\rfloor = 164.
Therefore, we want m=164 and m=163 orders. For m=164, we get
\cos\theta_{r} \amp = m\frac{\lambda}{2nd} \amp = 164\times \frac{0.530\ \mu\text{m}}{2\times 1.45\times 30\ \mu\text{m}} = 0.999.
Therefore,
\theta_{r} = 2.6^\circ.
For m=164, we get
\cos\theta_{r} = 163\times \frac{0.530\ \mu\text{m}}{2\times 1.45\times 30\ \mu\text{m}} = 0.993.
Therefore,
\theta_{r} = 6.8^\circ.
We want incidence angles corresponding to these refraction angles.
\theta_{i,164} \amp = \sin^{-1}\left( 1.45\sin 2.6^\circ\right) = 3.8^\circ. \theta_{i,163} \amp = \sin^{-1}\left( 1.45\sin 6.8^\circ\right) = 9.9^\circ.

exercise.title: Distance Between Constructive Interference due to Air Wedge

statement.p: A laser light of wavelength in air of 530\text{ nm} is incident on a wedge made of air between glass plates of refractive index 1.55. Find the distance along the wedge you need to move to go from one bright fringe to the next if the wedge angle is 2^\circ.

hint.p: Use constructive interference condition for wedge with n_1=n_3\gt n_2.

solution.p: For constructive interference from a wedge we get the following for order m. \[ 2\alpha x_m = m \dfrac{\lambda_2}{2},\ \ (m\ \text{ odd integer}) \] where \alpha is in radians, x_m the distance from the corner of the wedge to the m^{\text{th}}, \lambda_2 the wavelength in the medium of the wedge (air here). Therefore, the distance between two successive bright rings will be \[ x_m - x_{m-2} = 2\times \frac{1}{2\alpha}\dfrac{\lambda_2}{2} = \dfrac{530\:\text{nm}}{2\times 0.0349\:\text{rad}} = 7.6\:\mu\text{m}. \]

exercise.title: Radius of Curvature of a Lens from Number of Newtonian Rings

statement.p: A plano-convex lens made of glass of refractive index 1.55 is set on a flat surface with the curved part of the lens facing the flat surface. A light of wavelength 632.8\text{ nm} is shone on the lens from the above. One can see 60 bright rings from the center of the lens right up to the edge. What is the radius of curvature of the lens?

solution.p:
Here m=59 for the largest radius fringe.
r_{59} = \sqrt{59.5R\lambda_0},\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ R = \dfrac{r_{59}^2}{59.5\lambda_0}.
Putting in the numbers we obtain R = 37.7\:\mu\text{m}.
